places.name: Alexandria
places.description: The second largest city in Egypt and the largest city on the Mediterranean coast. Alexandria was the intellectual and cultural centre of the ancient Mediterranean for much of the Hellenistic age and late antiquity, particularly famous for its lighthouse and library.

persons.name: Alaric
persons.description: Leader of the Visigoths who led the sack of Rome in 410 CE.

persons.name: Theon
persons.description: of Alexandria, a Greek scholar and mathematician

persons.name: Hypatia
persons.description: a Neoplatonist philosopher, astronomer, and mathematician who lived in Alexandria, Egypt

places.name: Alexandria
places.description: The second largest city in Egypt and the largest city on the Mediterranean coast. Alexandria was the intellectual and cultural centre of the ancient Mediterranean for much of the Hellenistic age and late antiquity, particularly famous for its lighthouse and library.

persons.name: Hypatia
persons.description: a Neoplatonist philosopher, astronomer, and mathematician who lived in Alexandria, Egypt

places.name: Alexandria
places.description: The second largest city in Egypt and the largest city on the Mediterranean coast. Alexandria was the intellectual and cultural centre of the ancient Mediterranean for much of the Hellenistic age and late antiquity, particularly famous for its lighthouse and library.

persons.name: Umaribn al-Khattab
persons.description: Umar ibn al-Khattab, also spelled Omar, was the second Rashidun caliph, ruling from 634 until his assassination in 644. He is said to have ordered the destruction of the Library of Alexandria.

persons.name: Zoroaster
persons.description: Zoroaster, also known as Zarathustra, is regarded as the spiritual founder of Zoroastrianism.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

places.name: Arabian Peninsula
places.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

persons.name: Abū MūsāJābir ibn Ḥayyān
persons.description: the purported author of a large number of works in Arabic, often called the Jabirian corpus. His name is often latinized to Gebir or Geber.

persons.name: Abū Bakral-Rāzī
persons.description: often known as (al-)Razi or by his Latin name Rhazes, also rendered Rhasis, was a Persian physician, philosopher and alchemist who lived during the Islamic Golden Age

persons.name: Muhammad
persons.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

persons.name: AlbertusMagnus
persons.description: Wrote on natural philosophy. alchemy and much else besides. Bishop of Regensburg (Ratisbon), 1260-1262 and from 1931 a Doctor of the Church

persons.name: RogerBacon
persons.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

persons.name: RogerBacon
persons.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Heinrich CorneliusAgrippa
persons.description: Alchemist and occultist.

persons.name: Heinrich CorneliusAgrippa
persons.description: Alchemist and occultist.

places.name: Cologne
places.description: city spanning the Rhine River in western Germany

places.name: Lyon
places.description: Lyon is the third-largest city in France. It is located at the confluence of the Rivers Rhône and Saône, to the north-west of the French Alps.

persons.name: Catherinede' Medici
persons.description: an Italian noblewoman born into the Medici family. She was Queen of France from 1547 to 1559 by marriage to King Henry II and the mother of French kings Francis II, Charles IX, and Henry III.

persons.name: Paracelsus
persons.description: Born Theophrastus von Hohenheim Swiss physician, alchemist, lay theologian, and philosopher of the German Renaissance.

persons.name: Heinrich CorneliusAgrippa
persons.description: Alchemist and occultist.

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

persons.name: IbnSina
persons.description: Ibn Sina, commonly known in the West as Avicenna, was a preeminent philosopher and physician of the Muslim world.

persons.name: AeliusGalenus
persons.description: Often anglicised as Galen. He was a Greek and Roman physician, surgeon and philosopher. Galen's theory of the humoral body (composed of four liquids which must be balanced for good health) was influential.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: Paracelsus
persons.description: Born Theophrastus von Hohenheim Swiss physician, alchemist, lay theologian, and philosopher of the German Renaissance.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

persons.name: JakobBöhme
persons.description: A German philosopher, Christian mystic, and Lutheran Protestant theologian. His writings show influence by Neoplatonism and alchemy, while remaining within a Christian tradition

persons.name: BasilValentine
persons.description: If he existed a German alchemist, but might be an amalgam of a number of other alchemists.

persons.name: GeorgiusAgricola
persons.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

persons.name: GeorgiusAgricola
persons.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

persons.name: JohnPettus
persons.description: John Jones Pettus was an American politician, lawyer, and slave owner who served as the 23rd Governor of Mississippi, from 1859 to 1863.

persons.name: LazarusErcker
persons.description: a Bohemian metallurgist and assay master of a mint near Prague who wrote some of the earliest known treatises on metallurgy

persons.name: RobertFludd
persons.description: English physician and alchemist

persons.name: PierreGassendi
persons.description: French philosopher, Catholic priest, astronomer and mathematician who published the first data on the transit of Mercury in 1631.

persons.name: GalileoGalilei
persons.description: Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: JohannesKepler
persons.description: German mathematician, astonomer and natural philosopher who established a precise theory of planetary motion through his three laws.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: FrancisBacon

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: John JoachimBecher
persons.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
persons.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

persons.name: LouisDutens
persons.description: A French writer born in Tours, of Protestant parents, who lived most of his life in Britain or in British service on the continent.

persons.name: WilliamWhiston
persons.description: English (unorthodox) theologian, historian, natural philosopher, and mathematician. A leading figure in promoting the ideas of Isaac Newton whom he succeeded as Lucasian Professor.

persons.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
persons.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

persons.name: ThomasBurnet
persons.description: English theologian and writer on cosmogony. His work "Sacred Theory of the Earth" (London 1681, 1689) attempted to reconcile the biblical account of the creation of the Earth with geological findings.

persons.name: JohnKeil
persons.description: A Scottish mathematician, natural philosopher, and cryptographer who was an important defender of Isaac Newton.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.
